title: Floods, hail and banking inquiry sting RACQ earnings
text:
Member satisfaction edged down slightly while still remaining high at 89.9 per cent.

RACQ’s insurance arm – concentrated on home, vehicle and compulsory third-party insurance – posted an underwriting result of $73.1 million, down on $97.4 million.

A major factor was net wild weather insurance claims of $115 million, compared to the previous year’s $50.6 million. Big damage claims came from a hailstorm in southeast Queensland’s Gympie in October last year and the massive flood in Townsville in central Queensland in February this year.

But the insurance arm’s revenues also jumped 8.7 per cent in the year, up from $819 million to $890 million. Macquarie analysts, in a recent client note, argued that auto clubs such as RACQ were reaping greater market share.

That was partly as big ASX-listed insurers tried to recapture losses by jacking up prices nationally, providing a “comfortable price advantage” to more geographically focused insurers such as auto clubs, Macquarie analysts said.

The banking arm, acquired in the merger of QT Mutual in 2016, posted a deeper loss of $16.8 million against $8.5 million. Net interest income edged up slightly but other expenses also lifted, with Mr Gillespie saying additional investment had been made in technology.

He also said loans had grown more than 18 percent over the year, to $1.75 billion.

Yet RACQ has also stowed away a $5 million provision to compensate financial planning clients who might have been charged fees for no service, or who RACQ cannot show were given the services promised. A $1.2 million impairment charge was also notched against the financial planning arm.

Advertisement

Mr Gillespie said two remediation claims had been made to date, with the financial planning service having come following the merger. Other customer-owned institutions, such as CUA, have also been hit but the amounts are minute in comparison to big banks such as CBA, which has set aside more than $2 billion in remediation payouts.

RACQ has in recent years unsuccessfully sounded out other lenders to merge, including fellow mutuals QCCU and Heritage Bank, and ASX-listed Auswide. Questions have also been raised about whether its expansion has been slower than hoped.

But Mr Gillespie said growth had been heartening, and while RACQ remained focused on growing the bank naturally it was also open to any merger talks.

The result was buffered by a strong lift in investment returns in its insurance arm, and RACQ also acquired for $1.5 million the outstanding half of Autoglass, which offers repairs for members, insurance policyholders and commercial clients.

The other 50 per cent shareholder, Australian Automobile Clubs, had looked to exit its stake.

Mr Gillespie said it was launching its first mobile “advanced driver assistance systems” recalibration service – which helps recalibrate vehicle safety systems used in windscreens. The idea was to offer simultaneous windscreen replacement and recalibration, he said.

RACQ is Australia’s sixth-largest mutual by membership base, according to the latest Business Council of Cooperatives and Mutuals report.
description: But one of Australia's biggest member-owned associations argues customer numbers have risen, while satisfaction remains high.
